1.Title: Icelandic president will not stand for re-election - Yahoo News
1.Snippet: Iceland's President Guðni Thorlacius Jóhannesson will not stand for re-election in this year's presidential poll, the 55-year-old former history professor announced in his New Year's address on Monday, according to Icelandic broadcaster RUV. The presidential election is scheduled to take place on June 1, 2024. There are currently no declared candidates.

2.Title: 2024 Taiwanese presidential election - Wikipedia
2.Snippet: Presidential elections were held in Taiwan on 13 January 2024 as part of the 2024 general elections. Tsai Ing-wen of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), the incumbent president of the Republic of China, was ineligible for reelection due to term limits.As such, the DPP nominated Vice President Lai Ching-te, who had secured the party chairmanship by acclamation in March 2023.

Overview.Summary: In 2024, Iceland's President Guðni Th. Jóhannesson announced that he will not seek re-election in the upcoming presidential elections (1, 3). Eleven people are currently running for the office of President of Iceland (4). Comedian and former mayor of Reykjavík Jón Gnarr has announced his presidential bid (5). Prime Minister Katrin Jakobsdottir has resigned from her post to run for president (6). The presidential election is scheduled for June 1, 2024 (1, 2, 9). The Edda Award nominations were announced on February 16, with the ceremony taking place on April 13 (8). The embassy and honorary consuls in Canada and Costa Rica will allow absentee voting for Icelandic citizens (7).

Timeline.Text: Iceland's President Guðni Th. Jóhannesson announces he will not seek re-election in the upcoming presidential election in June 2024.
Comedian and former mayor of Reykjavík Jón Gnarr announces his presidential bid.
Iceland's prime minister Katrin Jakobsdottir resigns from her post to run for president in the upcoming election.
A total of 11 candidates are confirmed to be running for the office of the President of Iceland.
Absentee voting for the presidential election is available for Icelandic citizens in Canada and Costa Rica.
The presidential election is officially scheduled for June 1, 2024.
The nominations for the Edda Awards, which will be presented in April 2024, are announced.

Overview.Summary: The 2024 Icelandic presidential election will be held on June 1, 2024 (9, 10). The incumbent president, Guðni Th. Jóhannesson, announced in his New Year Address that he will not seek re-election (3). The leading opposition candidate, MarĂ­a Corina Machado, was barred from participating in the election (4). The election will be held in seven phases, with the results being declared on June 4, 2024 (6). Prabowo Subianto has been confirmed as the next president of Indonesia, beating two rival candidates (5). The election has been described as the largest in history, surpassing the previous election (6).

Timeline.Text: Iceland holds its presidential election, with incumbent president Guðni Th. Jóhannesson announcing he will not seek re-election.
Leading candidates María Corina Machado and Prabowo Subianto are barred from participating in the Venezuelan and Indonesian presidential elections, respectively.
The National Elections Authority announces the official results of the Egyptian presidential election, with Sisi winning with 89.6% of the vote.
Prabowo Subianto is formally confirmed as Indonesia's next president, beating his two rivals in the election.
The Venezuelan government and allies propose more than 20 different dates for the presidential election.
The new president of Iceland, who will commence their term on August 1, 2024, is elected.
Taiwan holds its presidential election, with Vice President Lai Ching-te securing the nomination for the Democratic Progressive Party.

The election is scheduled for June 1, 2024 and there are currently no declared candidates (1). The new president will commence their term on August 1, 2024 (3). This election will be part of the 2024 general elections in Taiwan (1). Iceland will hold a presidential election on June 1, 2024 (6).

Timeline.Text: Iceland's President Guðni Th. Jóhannesson announces that he will not seek re-election in the upcoming presidential election.
Iceland's prime minister Katrin Jakobsdottir resigns from her post to run for president.
The date of the Icelandic presidential election is modified to June 1, 2024.
Four candidates are given until this date to gather sufficient signatures to be added to the presidential candidates' list of recommendations.
An overview of Iceland's history and its current political system is provided.
The date of the Venezuelan presidential election is scheduled for July 28, 2024.
The date of the United States elections is scheduled for November 5, 2024.
